{{Infobox person |name = Dr. Abdel-Moniem ibn Ali El-Ganayni (عبد المنعم بن علي الجنايني) |image = |birth_date = 1950 |birth_place = Minyat Samannoud, Egypt |occupation = [[Physicist]] |nationality = [[United States|American]], [[Egypt]]ian }}
Dr. '''Abdel-Moniem ibn Ali El-Ganayni ''' ({{lang-ar|عبد المنعم بن علي الجنايني}}) is an [[Egypt]]ian-born [[United States|American]] [[nuclear physicist]], former prison [[Imam]], and an active member of the [[Pittsburgh]] [[Muslim]] community. In 2007 El-Ganayni's U.S. [[security clearance]] was revoked, and he subsequently lost his job as a senior scientist at [[Bettis Atomic Power Laboratory]].
==Biography== El-Ganayni was born in Minyat Samannoud, [[Egypt]] in 1950. His father, Sheikh Ali ibn Abdel-Moniem El-Ganayni (الشيخ علي بن عبدالمنعم الجنايني) was educated at the prestigious [[Al-Azhar University]], where he completed his elementary, secondary, and high school studies. Sheikh Ali proceeded to the Al-Azhar Faculty of [[Islamic Law]], where he completed the equivalent of a [[bachelor’s degree]]. He continued his studies to the graduate level, obtaining the equivalent of a [[Ph.D.]] in Islamic law (العالمية), and later a certification to practice law (إجازة القضاء الشرعي).
In 1973, Dr. Abdel-Moniem El-Ganayni obtained his Bachelor of Science in [[Physics]] from [[Ain Shams University]] in [[Cairo]], Egypt. He went on to pursue a [[Master's degree|master's]] in Nuclear Physics and completed his degree in 1978.
In 1980 El-Ganayni moved to the United States to complete his Ph.D., obtaining a second master's degree in Nuclear Physics from the [[University of Pittsburgh]] in 1983. Between 1984 and 1989 El-Ganayni worked as a teaching assistant in the Department of Physics, and completed his Ph.D. in Atomic Physics in 1990. He became an American citizen in 1988.
Shortly after completing his graduate studies, El-Ganayni was hired by [[Westinghouse Electric Company]], working in the Bettis Atomic Power Laboratory as a Senior Scientific Programmer, and later as a Senior Scientist. Throughout his employment at Bettis he received positive reviews, authored and coauthored a number of academic papers, and contributed to numerous projects.
El-Ganayni’s contributions were not limited to scientific endeavors; he is a founding member of the Islamic Center of Pittsburgh, served two terms as the center’s president, and helped to establish the mosque’s current location in Schenley Heights. For close to a decade, El-Ganayni worked and volunteered as an Imam at correctional facilities in both [[Ohio]] and [[Pennsylvania]]. Part of El-Ganayni’s prison outreach included the creation of the PA DOC Monitor, a website examining the condition, and necessary reform of the Department of Corrections.
== Loss of Security Clearance, Employment ==
Dr. El-Ganayni’s work at Bettis Atomic Power Laboratory required the possession of a [[United States Department of Energy|Department of Energy]] (DOE) issued security clearance, enabling him to work with [[classified information]]. In October 2007 El-Ganayni’s security clearance was suspended,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Memorandum_Order.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024211834/http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Memorandum_Order.pdf |archivedate=2012-10-24 |df= }}</ref> effectively barring him from any work at Bettis. DOE regulations stipulate that an individual may appeal a suspension, however El-Ganayni’s right to appeal was denied in May 2008 when Jeffery F. Kupfer, deputy secretary of the DOE, invoked [[national security]], refusing to reveal the government’s allegations against Dr. El-Ganayni.<ref>[http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/08179/893014-55.stm] - Muslim sues over loss of security clearance</ref>
The suspension of El-Ganayni’s security clearance was prefaced by an interview with DOE security officials, and later the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI). In these interviews, questions were asked regarding El-Ganayni’s political beliefs, religious views, and his work as an Imam in the prison system. No questions related to his work or any potential breaches of security were asked in either interview.
The DOE officials instead focused on a seemingly innocent Islamic book entitled, “The Miracle of the Ant,” authored by [[Turkey|Turkish]] Islamic publisher and author [[Harun Yahya]]; unbeknownst to El-Ganayni, the content of Yahya’s book was largely, if not completely duplicated from a [[Pulitzer Prize]] winning work entitled, “[[Journey to the Ants]]” published by [[Harvard University Press]].
Dr. El-Ganayni distributed excerpts from book to prisoners (both Muslim and non-Muslim) while serving as an Imam at Forest State Correctional Institution. DOE officials expressed concern over a purely scientific description of ants’ biological defense mechanisms in a chapter entitled, “Defense and War Tactics” insinuating that El-Ganayni distributed this material with sinister intent, and subsequently questioned his allegiance to the United States of America. His supervisor at Forest, chaplaincy director Glenn McQuown reviewed the book and described it as “completely benign.”
The interviews also focused on El-Ganayni’s criticism of American [[foreign policy]] and the FBI’s mistreatment of Muslims after [[September 11, 2001]]. Specifically, El-Ganayni raised concern over an FBI raid of a Pittsburgh mosque during Friday prayers, where attendees were searched and forced to stand outside while being questioned. Revocation of El-Ganayni’s security clearance also may be related to his establishment of the PA DOC Monitor, a website and prison outreach program which critically examines the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections and its policies, insisting that drastic reform of the system is required for it to truly benefit prisoners and society at large.<ref>[http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/08034/854427-85.stm] - Nuclear physicist/Muslim cleric fights to get job back, security clearance</ref>
== El-Ganayni vs. the United States Department of Energy et al.. ==
On June 26, 2008 the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU) with Schnader, Harrison, Segal, and Lewis as co-counsels filed a lawsuit on behalf of Dr. El-Ganayni alleging that the DOE revoked his clearance due to criticism of the FBI and U.S. foreign policy. The suit demands that the DOE reveal their allegations against El-Ganayni and restore due process, allowing him to contest any allegations made against him. A hearing date has not been set as of July 28, 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aclupa.org/pressroom/governmentrevokedmuslimnuc.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-07-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080903064152/http://aclupa.org/pressroom/governmentrevokedmuslimnuc.htm |archivedate=2008-09-03 |df= }} - Government Revoked Muslim Nuclear Physicist’s Security Clearance to Retaliate for Criticism of U.S. Policy, says ACLU</ref>
A motion for preliminary and permanent injunction against the U.S. Department of Energy and its acting director, Jeffrey Kupfer was filed on September 3, 2008 requesting the following:
* Assert that the court has jurisdiction over the case. * Order the Energy Department to show Dr. El-Ganayni the evidence it claims to have against him. * Order the Energy Department to hold a hearing where he can tell his side of the story, as provided in the agency's own rules for inquiries on sensitive security matters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aclupa.org/pressroom/governmentrevokedmuslimnuc.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-07-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080903064152/http://aclupa.org/pressroom/governmentrevokedmuslimnuc.htm |archivedate=2008-09-03 |df= }} - Muslim scientist asks judge to order hearing</ref>
On September 25, 2008 the DOE filed a motion to dismiss El-Ganayni's preliminary and permanent injunction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Govt_Motion_to_Dismiss_And_Oppose.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090219125734/http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Govt_Motion_to_Dismiss_And_Oppose.pdf |archivedate=2009-02-19 |df= }} - DOE Memorandum in Support of Motion to Dismiss and in Opposition to Plaintiff's Motion for Preliminary Injunction and Permanent Injunction</ref> On October 14, 2008 Dr. El-Ganayni's attorneys filed a brief in opposition of the DOE's motion to dismiss.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Brief_in_Opposition_to_Motion_to_Dismiss.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-10-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024195257/http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Brief_in_Opposition_to_Motion_to_Dismiss.pdf |archivedate=2012-10-24 |df= }} - Brief in Opposition to Motion to Dismiss</ref>
On October 31, 2008 Judge Terrence F. McVerry stated that the court "reluctantly concludes that it lacks subject-matter jurisdiction to adjudicate the claims made in Counts I and II of the Complaint" effectively granting the DOE's Motion to Dismiss in relation to Counts I and II. However, the court requested supplemental briefing regarding Count III, specifically concerning the DOE's interpretation, application, and adherence to executive procedure. Briefs from both the DOE and El-Ganayni's defense regarding Count III were submitted on November 14, 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Memorandum_Order.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024211834/http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Memorandum_Order.pdf |archivedate=2012-10-24 |df= }} -Memorandum 10-31-2008 in reference to DOE's motion to dismiss</ref>
Judge McVerry ruled in favor of Dr. El-Ganayni and refused to dismiss Count III on November 20, 2008. In his court order McVerry stated that, "[the] Defendants’ interpretation [of their own regulations] is not consistent with the actual text of the Executive Orders."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Order_denying_Motion_to_Dismiss_Count_III.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025002453/http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Order_denying_Motion_to_Dismiss_Count_III.pdf |archivedate=2012-10-25 |df= }}</ref> This ruling was based on a DOE regulation stating that a clearance can only be revoked by a DOE agency head, not simply a Deputy Secretary. Subsequently, November 24, 2008, a day before a scheduled hearing to discuss pending motions, future direction of the litigation, and the possible scheduling of a preliminary injunction hearing, DOE secretary Samuel Bodman signed a revocation of El-Ganayni's clearance citing national security and the government requested a dismissal of the case.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Notice_of_Filing.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025002534/http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Notice_of_Filing.pdf |archivedate=2012-10-25 |df= }}</ref> This dismissal was granted ,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Memorandum_Order_11_25_08.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025002852/http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Memorandum_Order_11_25_08.pdf |archivedate=2012-10-25 |df= }}</ref> however Dr. El-Ganayni appealed his case to the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court.<ref name="post-gazette.com">http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/08333/931314-52.stm</ref> Dr. El-Ganayni's brief for appeal of the dismissal was filed March 19, 2009 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Brief_for_Appeal_from_Grant_of_Motion_to_Dismiss.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025170032/http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/Brief_for_Appeal_from_Grant_of_Motion_to_Dismiss.pdf |archivedate=2012-10-25 |df= }}</ref> and a decision was made in the DOE's favor on January 11, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/3rd-circuit-opinion.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-02-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605000106/http://home.comcast.net/~halqahtani/abdelmoniem/3rd-circuit-opinion.pdf |archivedate=2011-06-05 |df= }}</ref> In summation, the judges stated that the DOE is by extension part of the government's Executive Branch, and therefore the 3rd Circuit has no jurisdiction over the matter.
== Leaving the United States ==
On November 26, 2008 El-Ganayni and his wife left to Egypt after residing in the United States for 28 years. El-Ganayni stated that he would rather return to his birthplace than live in America as a second-class citizen and that he "feel[s] very sad that the American people have lost a good bit of their Constitution," quoting John Adams who said, "once you lose your rights and liberties, it's very hard to get them back."<ref name="post-gazette.com"/>
==References== <references/>

The '''British undergraduate degree classification''' system is a [[Grade (education)|grading]] structure for [[undergraduate degree]]s or [[bachelor's degree]]s and [[Master's degree#Integrated Masters Degree|integrated master's degrees]] in the [[United Kingdom]]. The system has been applied (sometimes with significant variations) in other countries and regions.
== History == In the 16th century, the [[Regius Professor of Divinity]] at the [[University of Cambridge]] implemented [[Norm-referenced test|norm referencing]] to distinguish the top 25% of candidates, the next 50%, and the bottom 25%.{{cn|date=September 2018}}
The classification system as currently used in the United Kingdom was developed in 1918. Honours were then a means to recognise individuals who demonstrated depth of knowledge or originality, as opposed to relative achievement in examination conditions.
Recently{{when|date=September 2018}}, there has been concern over possible [[grade inflation]] due to increasing numbers of higher-class honours degrees awarded per annum. The number of first-class honours degrees has reportedly tripled since the 1990s. As with claimed grade inflation of [[GCE Advanced Level|A-levels]], prospective employers or educational institutions have observed increased difficulty in selecting candidates. It is, however, unknown whether the rise in the number of first-class degrees is due to grade inflation or whether students are achieving higher levels than in the past. University leaders have also pointed at the higher A-levels attained by students as evidence that higher degree grades should be expected. On the other hand, the practice of degree classification has been criticised for unduly stigmatising students and being unreflective of a graduate's success or potential for success, particularly in the workplace.
== Degree classification == A bachelor's degree can be an ''[[honours degree]]'' (bachelor's with honours) or an ''ordinary degree'' (bachelor's without honours). Honours degrees are classified, usually based on a [[weighted average]] (with higher weight given to marks in the later years of the course, and often zero weight to those in the first year) of the marks gained in exams and other assessments. Grade boundaries can vary by institution, but typical values are given below.
* First-class honours (1st, 1 or I) – typically 70% or higher * Second-class honours; ** Upper division (2:1, 2i or II-1) – typically 60–69% ** Lower division (2:2, 2ii or II-2) – typically 50–59% * Third-class honours (3rd, 3 or III) – typically 40–49%
Students who do not achieve honours may be awarded an ordinary degree, sometimes known as a "pass". Ordinary degrees, and other exit awards such as the [[Diploma of Higher Education]] (DipHE; for completing the first two years of a degree course) and [[Certificate of Higher Education]] (CertHE; for completing the first year of a degree course), may be unclassified (pass/fail) or, particularly in Scotland where the ordinary degree is offered as a qualification in its own right, classified into pass, merit and distinction. [[Foundation degree]]s are normally classified into pass, merit and distinction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.hull.ac.uk/fass/school-of-languages,-linguisti/undergraduate-study/student-handbook/general-university-regulations/your-degree-classification.aspx|title=Your degree classification|work=Student Handbook: General University Regulations|publisher=[[University of Hull]]|accessdate=16 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217142841/http://www2.hull.ac.uk/fass/school-of-languages,-linguisti/undergraduate-study/student-handbook/general-university-regulations/your-degree-classification.aspx|archivedate=17 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nottingham.ac.uk/academicservices/qualitymanual/assessmentandawards/degree-classification.aspx|title=Degree classification|publisher=[[University of Nottingham]]|accessdate=16 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170218063419/https://www.nottingham.ac.uk/academicservices/qualitymanual/assessmentandawards/degree-classification.aspx|archivedate=18 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Integrated master's degrees are usually classified with honours in the same way as a bachelor's honours degree, although some integrated master's degrees are classified like postgraduate taught master's degrees into pass (usually 50%), merit (60%) and distinction (70%).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.postgrad.com/advice/masters_programs/masters_degree_grades/|title=Masters Degree Grades|website=Postgrad.com|accessdate=16 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217143015/https://www.postgrad.com/advice/masters_programs/masters_degree_grades/|archivedate=17 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.uwe.ac.uk/students/academicadvice/degreeclassification.aspx|title=Degree classification|publisher=[[University of the West of England]]|accessdate=16 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217142754/http://www1.uwe.ac.uk/students/academicadvice/degreeclassification.aspx|archivedate=17 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
At most institutions, the system allows a small amount of discretion.<ref name="Seaton">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/apr/18/higher-education-degree-classification|title=Degree classification is unfair to many students|last=Seaton|first=Nigel|date=19 April 2011|work=The Guardian|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161202005614/https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/apr/18/higher-education-degree-classification|archivedate=2 December 2016|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> A candidate may be elevated to the next degree class if his or her average marks are close to (or the [[median]] of their weighted marks achieves) the higher class, and if they have submitted several pieces of work worthy of the higher class. However, even students with a high average mark may be unable to take honours if they have failed part of the course and so have insufficient credits.
In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, a bachelor's degree with honours normally takes three years of full-time study and usually requires 360 [[credit accumulation and transfer scheme|credits]], of which at least 90 are at level 6 (final year of a bachelor's degree) level, while an ordinary bachelor's degree normally requires 300 credits, of which 60 are at level 6.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.qaa.ac.uk/publications/information-and-guidance/publication?PubID=2730#.WKWxz6gXZoM|title=Higher education credit framework for England: guidance on academic credit arrangements in higher education in England|isbn=9781844828708|publisher=[[Quality Assurance Agency]]|date=August 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817191542/http://www.qaa.ac.uk/publications/information-and-guidance/publication?PubID=2730#.WKWxz6gXZoM|archivedate=17 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In Scotland, the honours bachelor's degree takes four years and requires 480 credits with a minimum of 90 at level 10 of the Scottish framework (last year of the honours degree) and 90 at level 9 (penultimate year), while the ordinary degree takes three years and requires 360 credits with a minimum of 60 at level 9 (last year of the ordinary degree).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scqf.org.uk/framework-diagram/Framework.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140616065231/http://scqf.org.uk/framework-diagram/Framework.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=16 June 2014|title=Interactive framework|accessdate=16 February 2017|publisher=SCQF}}</ref>
In Scotland, it is possible to start university a year younger than in the rest of the United Kingdom, as the Scottish [[Higher (Scottish)|Higher exams]] are often taken at age 16 or 17 (as opposed to 18), so Scottish students often end a four-year course at the same age as a student from elsewhere in the UK taking a three-year course, assuming no [[gap year]]s or students skipping the first year (direct entry to 2nd year).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/subjects/study-options/ug/degree-routes/direct-entry/|title=Direct entry to second year {{!}} University of St Andrews|website=www.st-andrews.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}}</ref>
When a candidate is awarded a degree with honours, "(Hons)" may be suffixed to their designatory letters — for example, BA (Hons), BSc (Hons), BMus (Hons), MA (Hons).<ref name=Eurydice>{{cite web|url=https://webgate.ec.europa.eu/fpfis/mwikis/eurydice/index.php/United-Kingdom-England:Bachelor#Certification|title=Bachelor|at=Certification|website=Eurydice|publisher=[[European Commission]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170220094322/https://webgate.ec.europa.eu/fpfis/mwikis/eurydice/index.php/United-Kingdom-England:Bachelor#Certification|archivedate=20 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> An MA (Hons) would generally indicate a degree award from certain Scottish universities (c.f. [[Scottish MA]]) and is at the same level as a bachelor's degree.
===Distribution of classes===
The [[Higher Education Statistics Agency]] (HESA) has published the number of degrees awarded with different classifications since 1994/5. The relative proportions of different classes have changed over this period, with increasing numbers of students being awarded higher honours. The table below shows the percentage of classified degrees (i.e. not including fails or unclassified degrees such as [[MBBS]]) in each class at five year intervals; note that HESA stopped giving statistics separately for third class honours and pass degree after 2003 and that a small number of undivided second class honours degrees (shown under "other" along with "unknown", which makes up the bulk of this category) were awarded up to 1996.

===First-class honours=== First-class honours, referred to as a "first", is the highest honours classification and indicates high academic achievement.
In 2010 and 2011, the [[Higher Education Statistics Agency]] (HESA) reported that approximately 15% of all degree candidates graduated with first-class honours.<ref name="Shepherd 1">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/mortarboard/2012/jan/12/first-class-degrees-concern|title=Is the number of first-class degrees cause for concern?|work=The Guardian|accessdate=30 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404024912/http://www.theguardian.com/education/mortarboard/2012/jan/12/first-class-degrees-concern|archivedate=4 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="HESA">[[Higher Education Statistics Agency]]. (2006.) [http://www.hesa.ac.uk/dox/dataTables/studentsAndQualifiers/download/quals0506.xls "Higher Education Qualifications Obtained in the UK by Level, Mode of Study, Domicile, Gender, Class of First Degree and Subject Area 2005/06"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071216060925/http://www.hesa.ac.uk/dox/dataTables/studentsAndQualifiers/download/quals0506.xls |date=16 December 2007 }}.</ref> The percentages of graduates achieving a first vary greatly by university and course studied.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cambridge.tab.co.uk/2012/11/10/the-secret-starred-first-student/|title=The Secret Tripos Topper|author="The Secret Tripos Topper"|date=10 November 2012|work=The Tab Cambridge|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20121115000000/http://cambridge.tab.co.uk/2012/11/10/the-secret-starred-first-student/|archivedate=15 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> For example, students of law are least likely to gain a first, whereas students of mathematical sciences are most likely to gain a first.<ref name="Shepherd 2">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/mortarboard/2012/jan/16/first-class-degrees-concern-update|title=Is the number of first-class degrees cause for concern: Update|first=Jessica|last=Shepherd|publisher=The Guardian|date=17 January 2012|accessdate=29 October 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150407101921/http://www.theguardian.com/education/mortarboard/2012/jan/16/first-class-degrees-concern-update|archivedate=7 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 2006–2007 and 2010–2011, 5.8% and 8.1% of law students gained a first, respectively; however, in those years, 28.9% and 30.0% of mathematics students gained a first, respectively.<ref name="Shepherd 2"/>
===Upper second-class honours {{anchor|Second-class honours}}=== {{Redirects here|2:1|an aspect ratio|Univisium}} The upper division is commonly abbreviated to "2:1" or "II.i" (pronounced ''two-one''). The 2:1 is a minimum requirement for entry to many postgraduate courses in the UK. It is also required for the award of a [[research council]] postgraduate studentship in the UK, although possession of a master's degree can render a candidate eligible for an award if their initial degree was below the 2:1 standard. The percentage of candidates who achieve upper second-class honours can vary widely by degree subject, as well as by university.<ref name="HESA"/>
===Lower second-class honours=== This is the lower division of second-class degrees and is abbreviated as "2:2" or "II.ii" (pronounced ''two-two''). It is also informally known as a "Desmond", named after [[Desmond Tutu]].
===Third-class honours=== Third-class honours, referred to as a "third", is the lowest honours classification in most modern universities. Historically, the University of Oxford awarded fourth-class honours degrees and, until the late 1970s, did not distinguish between upper and lower second-class honours degrees.<ref name="Alderman">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2003/oct/14/administration.highereducation|title=Tear up the class system|first=Geoffrey|last=Alderman|work=The Guardian|accessdate=31 July 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231000647/http://www.theguardian.com/education/2003/oct/14/administration.highereducation|archivedate=31 December 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Informally, the third-class honours degree is referred to as a "gentleman's degree" (''cf.'' the "gentleman's C" in the U.S.).<ref name="Henley">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/shortcuts/2012/jul/04/dont-judge-job-applicant-by-degree|title=Don't judge a job applicant by their degree|first=Jon|last=Henley|work=The Guardian|date=5 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161228211719/https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/shortcuts/2012/jul/04/dont-judge-job-applicant-by-degree|archivedate=28 December 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Approximately 7.2% of students graduating in 2006 with an honours degree received a third-class honours.<ref name="HESA"/>
===Ordinary degree=== While most university bachelor's degree courses lead to honours degrees, some universities offer courses leading to ordinary degrees.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ucas.com/ucas/undergraduate/getting-started/international-and-eu-students/ucas-terms-explained|title=UCAS terms explained|publisher=[[UCAS]]|accessdate=16 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217142621/https://www.ucas.com/ucas/undergraduate/getting-started/international-and-eu-students/ucas-terms-explained|archivedate=17 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Some honours courses permit students who do not gain sufficient credits in a year by a small margin to transfer to a parallel ordinary degree course. Ordinary degrees may also sometimes be awarded to honours degree students who do not pass sufficient credits in their final year to gain an honours degree, but pass enough to earn an ordinary degree.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/faculty.handbook/faqs/?faqno=552|title=Faculty Handbook Online 2013/14: Frequently Asked Questions|publisher=Durham University|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107040202/https://www.dur.ac.uk/faculty.handbook/faqs/?faqno=552|archivedate=7 November 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Some Scottish universities offer three-year ordinary degrees as a qualification in their own right, as well as an honours degree over four years. This is in contrast to English universities that have honours degrees with three years of study. An ordinary degree in Scotland is not a failed honours degree, as in certain English universities. Students can decide, usually at the end of their second or third year, whether or not they wish to complete a fourth honours year. Scottish universities may also award their ordinary degrees with distinction if a student achieves a particularly good grade average, usually 70% or above. A common example of a Scottish ordinary degree is the [[Bachelor of Laws]] course taken by graduates of other subjects, as this is sufficient (without honours) for entry into the legal profession. In other countries, Malawi for example, Mzuzu University offers four year ordinary degrees. The degree follows the same classification as those in the United Kingdom. Grades attained in the last two years ( year three and four) including internship and dissertation, contribute to the final degree classification.

University|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130803121333/http://www.aber.ac.uk/en/regulations/contents/aegrotat-awards/|archivedate=3 August 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite degrees are often qualified with an appended "(''aegrotat'')".
Following the introduction of current regulations regarding mitigating circumstances, ''aegrotat'' degrees are less commonly awarded than they previously were.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brookes.ac.uk/regulations/current/core/a1/a1-1-9/|title=''Aegrotat'' Awards|publisher=Oxford Brookes University|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160804043049/http://www.brookes.ac.uk/regulations/current/core/a1/a1-1-9/|archivedate=4 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Variations in classification===
At the [[University of Cambridge]], undergraduate [[Tripos]] examinations are split into three parts (e.g. Part IA, IB, and II), or two parts (Part I and II). Part II is taken at the end of final year. Each student receives a formal classification for each part (i.e. Class I, II.I, II.II, or III).<ref name="Cambridge">{{cite web|url=http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/univ/camdata/tripos.html|title=The structure of undergraduate courses at the University of Cambridge|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509185935/http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/univ/camdata/tripos.html|archivedate=9 May 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Typically, the Part II grade that corresponds with final examinations is quoted, but officially a grade simply exists for every Part of the degree, not for the overall degree.
At the [[University of Oxford]], a formal degree Class is given, and this is typically based on the final examinations. In Oxford, examinations for [[Prelims]] or [[Honour Moderations]] are also undertaken in first/second year, but these results do not typically affect the final degree classification. Until the 1970s, the four honours divisions in Oxford's moderations and final examinations were named first, second, third and fourth class, but eventually Oxford gave in and adopted the numbering used by other English universities.<ref name="Alderman"/>
====Variations of first-class honours====
At the [[University of Cambridge]], Triposes were previously split into two parts: Part I and Part II. Attaining First Class Honours in both parts would culminate in graduating with a "Double First".<ref name="Cambridge"/> Most Triposes were later split into three parts: "Part IA," "Part IB" and "Part II", or "Part I", "Part IIA" and "Part IIB". Attaining a First Class in all three parts culminates in graduating with a "Triple First".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.magd.cam.ac.uk/archaeology-and-anthropology-careers-and-talks/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-08-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819042048/http://www.magd.cam.ac.uk/archaeology-and-anthropology-careers-and-talks/ |archivedate=19 August 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.inference.phy.cam.ac.uk/mackay/cv.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-08-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415040644/http://www.inference.phy.cam.ac.uk/mackay/cv.pdf |archivedate=15 April 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cai.cam.ac.uk/sites/default/files/downloads/once_a_caian._issue_8.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-08-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818193029/https://www.cai.cam.ac.uk/sites/default/files/downloads/once_a_caian._issue_8.pdf |archivedate=18 August 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.society.caths.cam.ac.uk/Public_Magazines/1950r.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-08-03 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161006040604/http://www.society.caths.cam.ac.uk/Public_Magazines/1950r.pdf |archivedate=6 October 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HrJp7LU5NL0C&pg=PA318&lpg=PA318&ots=tNDjILyHrR&sig=Uyi7UKpQrt6xVhqGS5o07Auy59I&ved=0ahUKEwiUs-KwkqPOAhVkIcAKHWtPDWM4HhDoAQg4MAU&q=%22triple+first%22+cambridge|title=Musik im Exil: die Schweiz und das Ausland 1918-1945|first1=Chris|last1=Walton|first2=Antonio|last2=Baldassarre|date=29 December 2017|publisher=Peter Lang|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cambridgeeyetrust.org.uk/keithmartin.html|title=Cambridge Eye Trust - Professor Keith Martin|first=Peter|last=Watson|website=www.cambridgeeyetrust.org.uk|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819052951/http://www.cambridgeeyetrust.org.uk/keithmartin.html|archivedate=19 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The frequency of this honour varies with subject, but typically fewer than 3% of students will achieve this distinction. It is possible in some of the humanities Triposes to be awarded a "Starred First", for examination scripts that "consistently exhibit the qualities of first class answers to an exceptional degree."<ref name="CambStarred">{{cite web | url=http://www.phil.cam.ac.uk/curr-students/ugrads-exam-folder/marking-criteria-new | title=Undergraduate Examinations Guidelines for Examiners and Assessors for Tripos Examinations 2015 | publisher=University of Cambridge Faculty of Philosophy | accessdate=21 January 2015 | pages=9 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150121114046/http://www.phil.cam.ac.uk/curr-students/ugrads-exam-folder/marking-criteria-new | archivedate=21 January 2015 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> The science Triposes do not award Starred Firsts.
Oxford sometimes grants a congratulatory first, which ''[[The New York Times]]'' described as "a highly unusual honor in which the examining professors ask no questions about the candidate's written work but simply stand and applaud",<ref name="nyt20030614">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/14/world/sir-bernard-williams-73-oxford-philosopher-dies.html |title=Sir Bernard Williams, 73, Oxford Philosopher, Dies |last=Lehmann-Haupt |first=Christopher |date=2003-06-14 |newspaper=The New York Times |author-link=Christopher Lehmann-Haupt |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170106173405/http://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/14/world/sir-bernard-williams-73-oxford-philosopher-dies.html |archivedate=6 January 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and [[Martin Amis]] described as "the sort where you are called in for a [[thesis committee|viva]] and the examiners tell you how much they enjoyed reading your papers".<ref name=Zachary614>Leader, Zachary (2006). ''The Life of Kingsley Amis''. Cape, p. 614.</ref> A "double first" at Oxford usually informally refers to first-class honours in both components of an undergraduate degree, i.e. Moderations/Prelims and the Final Honour School, or in both the bachelor's and master's components of an integrated master's degree.
At [[University College London]], candidates who perform well beyond the requirements of a standard First Class Honours may be nominated to the [[Dean's List]]. This is generated once per year and recognizes outstanding academic achievement in final examinations. There are no set criteria for nomination to the list, but typically only a nominal number of students from each faculty are nominated per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mathematical-physical-sciences/about-the-faculty/faculty-prizes/deans-list|title=Dean's List commendees|website=www.ucl.ac.uk|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161012075200/https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mathematical-physical-sciences/about-the-faculty/faculty-prizes/deans-list|archivedate=12 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==International comparisons==
===France=== The University of St Andrews gives equivalences between French and British grades for its study-abroad programme.<ref name="St Andrews">{{cite web|title=Grade comparison of overseas qualifications|url=https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/media/registry/csa/creditandgradeconversions/France.pdf|publisher=University of St Andrews|accessdate=15 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161020161959/https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/media/registry/csa/creditandgradeconversions/France.pdf|archivedate=20 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Equivalencies for the purposes of initial teacher training have also been derived by the UK [[NARIC]] for 1st, 2:1 and 2:2 degrees, which do not align with St Andrews' table.<ref name=gov.uk>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/overseas-degree-equivalency-table-and-methodology|author=UK NARIC|publisher=National College for Teaching and Leadership|title=Overseas degree equivalency: table and methodology|date=28 May 2015|accessdate=15 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170129215739/https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/overseas-degree-equivalency-table-and-methodology|archivedate=29 January 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" border="1" ! rowspan="2"|British class !! colspan="2"|French grade range |- ! St Andrews !! UK NARIC |- |First || 15–20||16+ |- |Upper Second || 12–14||13+ |- |Lower Second || 10–11|| 12+ |- |Third || 7–9|| – |- |Pass || 6|| – |}
===South Africa=== The South African Qualifications Authority<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.saqa.org.za/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-08-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070816121445/http://www.saqa.org.za/ |archivedate=16 August 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> (SAQA) compares international degrees with local degrees before any international student continues their studies in that country. While the British degree accreditation and classification system allows students to go straight from a three-year bachelor's degree onto a master's degree (normally requiring a 1st or a 2:1 – those with a 2:2 or a 3rd usually require appropriate professional experience),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.prospects.ac.uk/postgraduate-study/masters-degrees/should-i-do-a-masters|title=Should I do a Masters?|publisher=Prospects|at=Can I do a Masters with a 2:2 or a third?|accessdate=15 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170216132355/https://www.prospects.ac.uk/postgraduate-study/masters-degrees/should-i-do-a-masters|archivedate=16 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> South Africa does not do so unless the student has proven research capabilities. South African Honours degrees prepare the students to undertake a research-specific degree (in terms of master's), by spending an in-depth year (up to 5 modules) creating research proposals and undertaking a research project of limited scope. This prepares students for the research degrees later in their academic career.
=== Spain === The UK NARIC has derived equivalencies for the grades of the Spanish ''grado'' and ''licenciatura'' degrees for purposes of initial teacher training bursaries.<ref name="gov.uk"/> {| class="wikitable" border="1" ! British class !! Spanish equivalent |- |First|| 8.5+ |- |Upper Second || 7+ |- |Lower Second || 6 + |}
===The Netherlands=== The Netherlands organisation for international cooperation in higher education (NUFFIC) has compared UK degree classification to Dutch degree grades.<ref name="Nuffic">{{cite web|last=Nuffic|title=Grading systems in the Netherlands, the United States and the United Kingdom|url=http://www.studyinholland.nl/documentation/grading-systems-in-the-netherlands-the-united-states-and-the-united-kingdom.pdf|publisher=www.studyinholland.nl|accessdate=27 March 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140328000513/http://www.studyinholland.nl/documentation/grading-systems-in-the-netherlands-the-united-states-and-the-united-kingdom.pdf|archivedate=28 March 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Dutch equivalencies have also been calculated by the UK NARIC.<ref name="gov.uk"/> {| class="wikitable" border="1" ! rowspan="2"|British class !! colspan="2"|Dutch equivalent |- ! NUFFIC !! UK NARIC |- |First|| 8-10 || 8.5+ |- |Upper Second || 7 to 8|| 6.5+ |- |Lower Second || 6 to 7|| 6+ |- |Third || 5.5 to 6 || – |} NUFFIC also noted that the grading culture is different in the Netherlands, so that it is very rare for even the best students in the Netherlands to be awarded a 9 or a 10, which represent near perfection and absolute perfection.<ref name="Nuffic"/>
===United States and Canada===
British honours degrees are sometimes considered equivalent (by British sources) to a US master's degree, with the US bachelor's degree being equivalent to a British pass degree, due to the much higher degree of specialisation in the UK.<ref>{{cite book|title=Quality and standards|chapter=Appendix 5: Higher education in other countries|url=https://www.leeds.ac.uk/educol/ncihe/a5_083.htm|quote=7.21 The team gained the impression, based on an inspection of syllabuses and examination papers, that the American high school diploma compares in standard with GCSE and the associate degree with GCE A-level and Advanced GNVQ, the bachelor’s degree with a UK pass degree or higher national diploma and the Master’s degree with a bachelor’s honours degree from a British university. Further evidence for this conclusion: Howard University in Washington, a university in which over 99 per cent of undergraduates are black, admits overseas applicants from the West Indies with five GCE O-level grades at A-C to the freshman year of their bachelor’s degree programme; Johns Hopkins, one of the most prestigious of the private universities, states in its prospectus that advanced placement is available for students entering with either International Baccalauréat or GCE A-level. The rider must be added, however, that an American education is very much more general than a UK education right up to bachelor’s level; it would hardly be reasonable, therefore, to expect the same standard to be reached in the major subject. It was also noted that, in the highest quality institutions, some individual modules taken by senior students compared well in level with UK final honours standard. A given student would take rather fewer of these more demanding modules than a UK student, however.|work=[[Dearing Report|The National Committee of Enquiry into Higher Education (Dearing Report)]]|author=[[Ronald Dearing, Baron Dearing|Ron Dearing]]|date=23 July 1997|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171024033713/http://www.leeds.ac.uk/educol/ncihe/a5_083.htm|archivedate=24 October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britishcouncil.org:80/eis/quusa.htm|title=Comparing your US qualifications with those in the UK|publisher=[[British Council]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20021001135341/http://www.britishcouncil.org/eis/quusa.htm|archive-date=1 October 2002|quote=Master's degree - in terms of specialisation, the American Master's degree from prestigious colleges and universities is considered comparable to the British Bachelor (Honours) degree. Candidates who have followed academically rigorous programmes have reached a standard comparable to that of a British taught Master's degree.|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, many British institutions accept US bachelor's degrees for admission to postgraduate study (see below) and US comparison services treat British and American degrees as equivalent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wenr.wes.org/2016/02/education-in-the-u-k|title=Education in the U.K.|publisher=[[World Education Services]]|date=2 February 2016|accessdate=26 May 2017|quote=The programs result in degrees such as the Bachelor of Arts, Bachelor of Science, Bachelor of Engineering, Bachelor of Laws, and Bachelor of Education, all of which are equivalent to a bachelor’s degree in the U.S. system.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161030191855/http://wenr.wes.org/2016/02/education-in-the-u-k|archivedate=30 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> When US bachelor's degrees are compared to British honours degrees, equivalencies can be expressed in terms of either [[Academic grading in the United States#Grade point average|US Grade Point Averages]] (GPAs) or letter grades.
British institutions normally state equivalence in terms of GPAs. Approximate mappings between British classifications and GPAs can be inferred from the graduate admissions criteria used by British universities, which often give international equivalents. GPA">[http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate-study/application-admission/general-entrance-requirement General entrance requirements], ''[[University College London]]'' {{webarchive 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Similarly, the UK NARIC gives equivalent GPAs for determining eligibility for teacher training bursaries.<ref name="gov.uk"/> In contrast, [[Durham University]]'s ''North American Undergraduate Guide 2017'' gives a conversion table as a guide to understanding British classifications (rather than for admission to postgraduate study) of 1st = 3.8–4.0, 2:1 = 3.3–3.7, 2:2 = 2.8–3.2 and 3rd = 2.3–2.7.<ref name="Durham GPA">{{cite book|url=https://issuu.com/communicationsoffice/docs/4230-duio_ug_north_america_brochure|title=North American Undergraduate Guide|publisher=Durham University|date=20 August 2017|website=ISSUU|accessdate=3 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180506164715/https://issuu.com/communicationsoffice/docs/4230-duio_ug_north_america_brochure|archivedate=6 May 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The GPA conversions are summarised in the following table:

UCL<ref name="UCL GPA"/>!!Durham<ref name="Durham GPA"/>!!NARIC<ref name="gov.uk"/>!!Other |- |First||3.6+||3.8–4.0|| 3.7+ ||3.8+ (Oxford)<ref name="Oxford English Language and Literature entrance requirement"/> |- |Upper Second||3.3+||3.3–3.7|| 3.2+||3.5+ (LSE)<ref name="LSE entrance requirement"/> |- |Lower Second||3.0+||2.8–3.2|| 2.6+|| – |- |Third|| – ||2.3–2.7|| – || – |}
Letter grade equivalents are more commonly used by American institutions. [[World Education Services]] (WES),<ref name="WES conversion">{{cite web|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040504181657/http://www.wes.org/gradeconversionguide/unitedkingdom.htm|url=http://www.wes.org:80/gradeconversionguide/unitedkingdom.htm|archive-date=4 May 2004|accessdate=15 February 2017|title=United Kingdom|work=INTERNATIONAL GRADE CONVERSION GUIDE FOR HIGHER EDUCATION|publisher=World Education Services|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> a nonprofit organisation which provides qualification conversion services to many universities and employers, gives 1st = A, 2:1 = A-/B+, 2:2 = B, 3rd = B-, Pass = C, which would convert British degrees to higher GPAs than the conversion used by UCL if the guidelines for converting grades to GPA given by [[Duke University]]<ref name="Duke grade to GPA conversion">{{cite web|url=https://gradschool.duke.edu/admissions/apply/gpa|title=GPA|publisher=Duke University|accessdate=15 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170227063259/https://gradschool.duke.edu/admissions/apply/gpa|archivedate=27 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> are used. The [[Fulbright Commission]] has also created "an unofficial chart with approximate grade conversions between UK results and US GPA."<ref name="Fulbright Commission">{{cite web|url=http://www.fulbright.org.uk/study-in-the-usa/postgraduate-study/applying/transcript#how%20do%20i%20convert|title=Transcript – Postgraduate Study|publisher=US – UK Fulbright Commission|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130709002217/http://www.fulbright.org.uk/study-in-the-usa/postgraduate-study/applying/transcript#how%20do%20i%20convert|archivedate=9 July 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

Grade !! GPA |- ! First | style="text-align:center;" |A||4.00 ||A||4.0 |- ! Upper Second | style="text-align:center;" |A-/B+||3.33–3.67||A-/B+||3.7/3.3 |- ! Lower Second | style="text-align:center;" |B||3.00|| B||3.0 |- ! Third | style="text-align:center;" |C+||2.30 ||B-||2.7 |- ! Pass | style="text-align:center;" |C||2.00 ||C||2.0 |}
[[Academic grading in Canada|Canadian academic grades]] may be given as letters, percentages, 12-point GPAs or 4-point GPAs. The 4-point GPAs are sometimes seen to differ from the US but other sources treat them as equivalent. The Durham conversion specifies GPAs for the US and letter grades/percentages for Canada<ref name="Durham GPA"/> while the UK NARIC has separate GPA conversions for the four-year bachelor's honours, baccalauréat and professional bachelor's degrees (which differ from their US GPA equivalents by at most 0.1) and the three-year bachelor's degree (which is seen as a lower standard).<ref name="gov.uk"/> The ''British Graduate Admissions Fact Sheet'' from [[McGill University]] uses the conversion 1st = 4.0; 2:1 = 3.0; 2:2 = 2.7; 3rd = 2.0; Pass = 1.0; Fail = 0.0.<ref name="McGill equiv">{{cite web|url=https://secureweb.mcgill.ca/gradapplicants/sites/mcgill.ca.gradapplicants/files/UNITED_KINGDOM.pdf|title=Future graduate students: European Fact Sheets – UK|publisher=McGill University|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403132112/https://secureweb.mcgill.ca/gradapplicants/sites/mcgill.ca.gradapplicants/files/UNITED_KINGDOM.pdf|archive-date=3 April 2015|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
{|class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan=3| British degree<br>classification ! rowspan="2" colspan=2|Canadian equivalent<br>(Durham)<ref name="Durham GPA"/> ! colspan=8| Canadian GPA equivalent (NARIC)<ref name="gov.uk"/> ! rowspan=3| Canadian GPA<br>equivalent<br>(McGill)<ref name="McGill equiv"/> |- ! colspan=4| 4-year (Bachelor Honours degree) ! colspan=4|3-year (Bachelor's degree) |- ! % ! Letter ! GPA ! % ! Letter ! 12-point ! GPA ! % ! Letter ! 12-point |- | First||85%+||A – A+||3.7+||73%||A-||10||3.9+||90%||A||12||4.0 |- |Upper Second||77% – 84%||B+ – A-||3.1+||73%||B||8||3.5+||80%||B+||10||3.0 |- |Lower Second||67% – 76%||C+ – B-||2.5||62%||C+||6||3.1||73%||B||8||2.7 |- |Third||60% - 66%|| – ||colspan=4| – ||colspan=4| – ||2.0 |- |Pass||colspan=2| – ||colspan=4| – ||colspan=4| – ||1.0 |}
Degrees in the UK are mapped to levels of the [[Frameworks for Higher Education Qualifications of UK Degree-Awarding Bodies]] (FHEQ), which includes the Framework for Qualifications of Higher Education Institutes in Scotland (FQHEIS), which has an alternative numbering of levels corresponding to those of the Scottish Credit and Qualifications Framework (SCQF). Bachelor's degrees (including the [[Scottish MA]], but not including [[MB BS|medical degrees]], dentistry degrees or degrees in veterinary science) attained in the UK are at FHEQ level 6/FQHEIS level 9 (ordinary) or 10 (honours); master's degrees (including integrated master's degrees and first degrees in medicine, dentistry and veterinary science) are at FHEQ level 7/FQHEIS level 11, and doctoral degrees are at FHEQ level 8/FQHEIS level 12. Bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees map to first, second and third cycle qualifications in the [[Bologna Process#Qualifications Framework of the European Higher Education Area|Qualifications Framework of the European Higher Education Area]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scqf.org.uk/framework-diagram/Framework.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140616065231/http://scqf.org.uk/framework-diagram/Framework.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2014-06-16|title=The Scottish Credit and Qualifications Framework}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.qaa.ac.uk/en/Publications/Documents/qualifications-frameworks.pdf|title=The Frameworks for Higher Education Qualifications of UK Degree-Awarding Bodies|publisher=[[Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education]]|date=November 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305083730/http://www.qaa.ac.uk/en/Publications/Documents/qualifications-frameworks.pdf|archivedate=5 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Progression to postgraduate study== Regulations governing the progression of undergraduate degree graduates to postgraduate programmes vary among universities, and are often flexible. A candidate for a postgraduate master's degree is usually required to have at least a 2:2 bachelor honours degree, although candidates with 2:1s are in a considerably stronger position to gain a place in a postgraduate course and to obtain funding, especially in medical and natural sciences. Some institutions specify a 2:1 minimum for certain types of master's program, such as for a [[Master of Research]] course.<ref>[http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/univ/gsprospectus/applying/entry.html Entrance requirements: Graduate Prospectus 2010–11] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913073724/http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/univ/gsprospectus/applying/entry.html |date=13 September 2008 }}, ''[[University of Cambridge]]'', September 2009</ref><ref>[https://lfylive.lse.ac.uk/lfy/tc/enquiries/enquiry.html?a=4&q=565 What are the entry requirements for graduate programmes at LSE?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111009014628/https://lfylive.lse.ac.uk/lfy/tc/enquiries/enquiry.html?a=4&q=565 |date=9 October 2011 }}, ''[[London School of Economics]]''</ref>
Candidates with a Third or an Ordinary degree are sometimes accepted, provided they have acquired satisfactory professional experience subsequent to graduation. A candidate for a doctoral programme who does not hold a master's degree is nearly always required to have a First or 2:1 at bachelor's level.
==Variations==
===International degrees===
====Australia==== Some universities, such as those in Australia, offer ordinary or pass degrees, (for instance, as a three-year B.A. or a three-year BSc) by default. High-achieving students may be recognised with an honours classification without further coursework or research, as is often the case in engineering, which often contains a research and thesis component,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://handbook.unimelb.edu.au/view/2012/B-ENG|title=BEng (Bachelor of Engineering)|work=University of Melbourne Handbook|publisher=University of Melbourne|accessdate=31 July 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130722101206/https://handbook.unimelb.edu.au/view/2012/B-ENG|archivedate=22 July 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eng.unsw.edu.au/info-about/our-faculty/faculty-policies/honours-policy|title=Honours Policy|publisher=Faculty of Engineering, University of New South Wales|accessdate=31 July 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130702165314/http://www.eng.unsw.edu.au/info-about/our-faculty/faculty-policies/honours-policy|archivedate=2 July 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> or law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law.unsw.edu.au/current-students/my-academic-life/honours|title=Honours|publisher=UNSW Faculty of Law|accessdate=31 July 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516014028/http://www.law.unsw.edu.au/current-students/my-academic-life/honours|archivedate=16 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, other courses (such as humanities, arts, social sciences, and sciences) and other universities may recognise high-achieving students with an honours classification with further coursework or research, undertaken either concurrently with, and as part of or in addition to, a bachelor's course,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sydney.edu.au/law/cstudent/undergrad/honours_program.shtml|title="New" Honours Program|publisher=Sydney Law School|accessdate=31 July 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130716063911/http://sydney.edu.au/law/cstudent/undergrad/honours_program.shtml|archivedate=16 July 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> or after completion of a bachelor's course requirements and attaining adequately competitive grades.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maths.unsw.edu.au/currentstudents/honours-mathematics-and-statistics|title=The Honours Year|publisher=School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of New South Wales|accessdate=31 July 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130813034354/http://www.maths.unsw.edu.au/currentstudents/honours-mathematics-and-statistics|archivedate=13 August 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asb.unsw.edu.au/schools/economics/programsandcourses/honours/Pages/default.aspx|title=Honours – Programs & courses – Economics|publisher=Australian School of Business, University of New South Wales|accessdate=31 July 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131003205335/http://www.asb.unsw.edu.au/schools/economics/programsandcourses/honours/Pages/default.aspx|archivedate=3 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Some graduate degrees have been or are classified;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law.unsw.edu.au/sites/law.unsw.edu.au/files/honoursinfosheet_s2_2011_u1_2012_jd.pdf|title=Award of Honours in the Juris Doctor (JD) Degree|publisher=UNSW Faculty of Law|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130614065352/http://www.law.unsw.edu.au/sites/law.unsw.edu.au/files/honoursinfosheet_s2_2011_u1_2012_jd.pdf|archivedate=14 June 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> however, under the [[Australian Qualifications Framework]] (AQF), no graduate-level degrees (i.e., master's by coursework, master's by research, or higher research degrees) may be classified. To comply with this standard, some institutions have commenced, or will commence, offering high-achieving graduates with "distinction".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law.unsw.edu.au/sites/law.unsw.edu.au/files/images/jd_honours_policy_from_2015.pdf|title=Law JD Honours as of 2015|publisher=UNSW Faculty of Law|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403133957/http://www.law.unsw.edu.au/sites/law.unsw.edu.au/files/images/jd_honours_policy_from_2015.pdf|archivedate=3 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Notably, this is consistent with British graduate degree classification.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/resources/calendar/academicregulations/taughtmastersdegreesfourunits.htm|title=Taught Masters Degree|publisher=London School of Economics|accessdate=31 July 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130719070843/http://www.lse.ac.uk/resources/calendar/academicregulations/taughtmastersdegreesfourunits.htm|archivedate=19 July 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===British medical and dental degrees=== In the United Kingdom, medicine is usually taught as an undergraduate course, with graduates being awarded a master's level qualification: normally the conjoined degrees of [[Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery]] (MBBS, BM BCh, MB ChB, etc.) although at [[Queen's University Belfast]] (and universities in Ireland) Bachelor in the Art of Obstetrics (BAO) is added, and at some universities only the [[Bachelor of Medicine]] is awarded - all of these have equal standing. Unlike most undergraduate degrees, the MBBS is not normally considered an honours degree, and thus is not classified into first class honours, etc. Students may be awarded "Merits" and "Distinctions" for parts of the course or the whole course (depending on the institution) and "Honours" may be awarded at some institutions for exceptional performance throughout the course (as a grade above Distinction).<ref name="QAA medicine">{{cite web|url=http://www.qaa.ac.uk/en/Publications/Documents/Subject-benchmark-statement-Medicine.pdf|title=Subject benchmark statement - Medicine|publisher=[[Quality Assurance Agency]]|accessdate=23 February 2017|date=2002|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160122221116/http://www.qaa.ac.uk/en/Publications/Documents/Subject-benchmark-statement-Medicine.pdf|archivedate=22 January 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncl.ac.uk/regulations/programme/2016-2017/documents/A101A1001500UProgrammeRegulations.pdf|title=MBBS Programme Regulations 2016/17|publisher=[[Newcastle University]]|accessdate=23 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223125936/http://www.ncl.ac.uk/regulations/programme/2016-2017/documents/A101A1001500UProgrammeRegulations.pdf|archivedate=23 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Medical schools split their year groups into one of 10 [[decile]]s. These deciles are the major factor in the calculation of Educational Performance Measure (EPM) points used as part of medical students' [[Foundation Programme]] applications, with the top decile receiving 43 points, decreasing by a point for each decile (so the lowest gets 34 points); 7 points can be awarded for other educational achievements (other degrees and publications), and the EPM points are combined with up to 50 points from the Situational Judgement Test to give a total out of 100.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foundationprogramme.nhs.uk/pages/fp-afp/faqs/EPM|title=EPM FAQs|publisher=[[National Health Service]]|accessdate=23 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223130240/http://www.foundationprogramme.nhs.uk/pages/fp-afp/faqs/EPM|archivedate=23 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foundationprogramme.nhs.uk/download.asp?file=FP_AFP_Applicants_Handbook_2017.pdf|title=FP/AFP 2017 Applicant's Handbook|publisher=[[National Health Service]]|accessdate=23 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223212536/http://www.foundationprogramme.nhs.uk/download.asp?file=FP_AFP_Applicants_Handbook_2017.pdf|archivedate=23 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==British Grade Point Average== Following the recommendation of the Burgess report into the honours degree classification system in 2007, the [[Higher Education Academy]] ran a pilot in 2013–2014 in collaboration with 21 institutions delivering higher education (ranging from [[Russell Group]] universities to [[Further Education]] colleges) to investigate how a Grade Point Average (GPA) system would work best in Britain. Two main weighting systems were tested: an American-style average of all marks, weighted only by credit value, and weighting by "exit velocity" in the manner of the honours classification, where modules in the first year are given a low or zero weight and modules in the final year have a higher weight (a third model was only rarely used). Over two thirds of providers preferred exit-velocity weighting to the straight average.<ref name="GPA report">{{cite web|url=https://www.heacademy.ac.uk/resource/grade-point-average-report-gpa-pilot-project-2013-14|title=Grade point average: Report of the GPA pilot project 2013-14|date=28 May 2015|publisher=Higher Education Academy|accessdate=23 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224134517/https://www.heacademy.ac.uk/resource/grade-point-average-report-gpa-pilot-project-2013-14|archivedate=24 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
A GPA scale, tied to percentage marks and letter grades, was recommended for use nationally following the study, to run in parallel with the honours degree classification system.<ref name="GPA report"/>

[[File:De Finetti diagram.svg|thumb|right|A de Finetti diagram. The curved line is the expected [[Hardy-Weinberg principle|Hardy-Weinberg frequency]] as a function of ''p''.]] A '''de Finetti diagram''' is a [[ternary plot]] used in [[population genetics]]. It is named after the [[Italy|Italian]] [[statistics|statistician]] [[Bruno de Finetti]] (1906–1985) and is used to graph the [[genotype frequency|genotype frequencies]] of [[population]]s, where there are two [[allele]]s and the population is [[diploidy|diploid]]. It is based on an [[equilateral triangle]], and [[Viviani's theorem]] concerning any point within the triangle, and the three lines from that point that are perpendicular to the sides of the triangle. The sum of the lengths of the lines is a fixed value, regardless of the position of the point. This value (the sum of the lengths) is set to be 1.
==Applications in genetics==
The de Finetti diagram has been put to extensive use in population genetics by [[A.W.F. Edwards]] in his book ''Foundations of Mathematical Genetics''. In its simplest form the diagram can be used to show the range of genotype frequencies for which [[Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium]] is satisfied (the curve within the diagram). [[A.W.F. Edwards]] and [[Chris Cannings]] extended its use to demonstrate the changes that occur in allele frequencies under [[natural selection]].
==See also== * [[Wahlund effect]]
==References== * Cannings C., Edwards A.W.F. (1968) "Natural selection and the de Finetti diagram" ''Ann Hum Gen'' '''31''':421-428 * Edwards, A.W.F. (2000) ''Foundations of Mathematical Genetics 2nd Edition'', Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-521-77544-1}} {{page needed|date=October 2016}}
==External links== * [https://finetti.meb.uni-bonn.de Online plotting of ''de Finetti'' diagrams for population genetics] (also calculates [[Hardy Weinberg]] equilibrium statistics)
